description: A laboratory-based course on fabricating microelectronic and micromechanical devices using photolithographic processing and related fabrication technologies. Lectures discuss: clean room procedures; microelectronic and microstructural materials; photolithography; diffusion, oxidation; materials deposition; etching and plasma processes. Basic laboratory processes are covered for the first two thirds of the course with students completing structures appropriate to their major in the final third. Students registering for ESE 574 will be expected to do extra work (including term paper and additional project).
name: LABORATORY

values.comments:
This is a laboratory-based course on fabricating microelectronic and micromechanical devices using photolithographic processing and related fabrication technologies. The lectures discuss clean room procedures, microelectronic and microstructural materials, photolithography, diffusion, oxidation, materials deposition, etching and plasma processes. Basic laboratory processes are covered for the first two thirds of the course with students completing structures appropriate to their major in the final third. 

Most of the students that took this course found it to be “disorganized” and said that the course material had “no direction.” In addition, many students found little value in the assigned readings because the lecture material had “no consistency with the book.” 

For the most part, students criticized Professor Santiago’s teaching style. According to many, he didn’t go through many practice problems during the semester “until the final review session.” They also said that Professor Santiago never specifically assigned which sections of the textbook to focus on. In addition, some students reported that Professor Santiago often didn’t keep his office hours and that he was “difficult to get in contact with.” 

Most of the students that took this class were upperclassmen in the Electrical Engineering major. They said that reviewing for exams in this class was difficult because Professor Santiago took “a long time to get homework back.” Students also found Professor Santiago’s grading somewhat unfair. Some agreed that Professor Santiago “penalized students heavily for writing too little,” while he suggested writing short answers to his questions prior to the exam.
